unnormalised: Travelling in India can be a bit of an adventure, especially when it comes to booking and managing your tickets. Whether it's trains, buses, or flights, understanding the various identifiers involved can save you a lot of headaches. Let's break down some of the key identifiers you'll likely encounter.
normalised: Travelling in India can be a bit of an adventure, especially when it comes to booking and managing your tickets. Whether it's trains, buses, or flights, understanding the various identifiers involved can save you a lot of headaches. Let's break down some of the key identifiers you'll likely encounter.

unnormalised: First off, train travel is a quintessential Indian experience. The PNR, or Passenger Name Record, is your golden ticket here. You'll find this 10-digit number (e.g., 1234567890) on your e-ticket or printed reservation slip. Keep this PNR handy, as it’s essential for checking your reservation status, tracking your train, and even claiming refunds if needed. Pro tip: you can easily check the PNR status on the IRCTC website or via various travel apps.
normalised: First off, train travel is a quintessential Indian experience. The P-N-R, or Passenger Name Record, is your golden ticket here. You'll find this ten-digit number (e.g., one two three four five six seven eight nine zero) on your e-ticket or printed reservation slip. Keep this P-N-R handy, as it's essential for checking your reservation status, tracking your train, and even claiming refunds if needed. Pro tip: you can easily check the P-N-R status on the I-R-C-T-C website or via various travel apps.

unnormalised: Next, let's talk about buses. Online bus booking platforms often assign a booking ID (e.g., BKID12345) to your reservation. This ID is crucial for confirming your booking with the bus operator. Some operators also issue a ticket number (e.g., TKT-56789). Always double-check these numbers against your payment confirmation to avoid any last-minute surprises. Remember that redBus uses their own ID, like RB123456.
normalised: Next, let's talk about buses. Online bus booking platforms often assign a booking I-D (e.g., B-K-I-D one two three four five) to your reservation. This I-D is crucial for confirming your booking with the bus operator. Some operators also issue a ticket number (e.g., T-K-T five six seven eight nine). Always double-check these numbers against your payment confirmation to avoid any last-minute surprises. Remember that redBus uses their own I-D, like R-B one two three four five six.

unnormalised: Flying, of course, comes with its own set of identifiers. Your airline PNR or booking reference (often a 6-character alphanumeric code like ABCDEFG) is your primary identifier. Airlines like IndiGo, SpiceJet, and Air India each use their own systems, but the principle remains the same. Plus, the e-ticket number, typically a 13-digit code (e.g., 123-4567890123), is also vital, particularly when dealing with customer service or modifications.
normalised: Flying, of course, comes with its own set of identifiers. Your airline P-N-R or booking reference (often a six-character alphanumeric code like A-B-C-D-E-F-G) is your primary identifier. Airlines like IndiGo, SpiceJet, and Air India each use their own systems, but the principle remains the same. Plus, the e-ticket number, typically a thirteen-digit code (e.g., one two three dash four five six seven eight nine zero one two three), is also vital, particularly when dealing with customer service or modifications.

unnormalised: Don't forget the flight number! This simple combination of letters and numbers (e.g., 6E201 or AI444) identifies your specific flight. It's useful for tracking the flight's progress and confirming departure/arrival times.
normalised: Don't forget the flight number! This simple combination of letters and numbers (e.g., six E two zero one or A-I four four four) identifies your specific flight. It's useful for tracking the flight's progress and confirming departure or arrival times.

unnormalised: Aadhaar is increasingly used as a primary ID when booking, especially for senior citizens availing concessions. Ensure the Aadhaar number (e.g., 1234 5678 9012) is correctly entered to avoid any issues at the time of boarding.
normalised: Aadhaar is increasingly used as a primary I-D when booking, especially for senior citizens availing concessions. Ensure the Aadhaar number (e.g., one two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two) is correctly entered to avoid any issues at the time of boarding.

unnormalised: Then there’s the ticket class; from 1A to 3A, SL, or general, each code represents a different class. Be familiar with these to avoid confusion.
normalised: Then there’s the ticket class; from one A to three A, S-L, or general, each code represents a different class. Be familiar with these to avoid confusion.

unnormalised: Finally, when using travel aggregators like MakeMyTrip or Yatra, you’ll often receive their own internal booking IDs, alongside the airline or train’s PNR. For instance, MakeMyTrip might give you an ID like MT1234567. While these IDs are helpful for tracking your booking on their platform, the original PNR or booking reference is what you'll need when dealing directly with the airline or railway. So, while the world of travel identifiers may seem a bit complex, a little understanding goes a long way in ensuring a smooth and stress-free journey across India. Happy travels!
